Description: Flat body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery plate; glaze mostly fired orange-red; top: black-figure decoration probably consisting of confronted sphinxes; to left, remains of pendant palmette; to right, sphinx facing left, only buttocks missing; added red on chest and wing); incised blobs and splinter rosettes as filling ornament; below, narrow band; underside: surface mostly destroyed apart from slight traces of red and incision in one corner.
Producer name: Attributed to an Apprentice/Pupil of: The Polos Painter
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 474, no. B817)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 227, no. 12 (above))
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0802) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
